name: apple
fun_fact: Apples float in water because they're 25% air.

name: banana
fun_fact: Bananas are berries, but strawberries aren't.

name: orange
fun_fact: The color orange was named after the fruit, not the other way around.

name: strawberry
fun_fact: Strawberries have their seeds on the outside — about 200 per berry.

name: blueberry
fun_fact: Blueberries are one of the only naturally blue foods.

name: raspberry
fun_fact: A single raspberry is made up of about 100 tiny individual fruits called drupelets.

name: blackberry
fun_fact: Blackberries are technically not berries — they're aggregate fruits.

name: grape
fun_fact: It takes about 2.5 pounds of grapes to make one bottle of wine.

name: watermelon
fun_fact: Watermelon is 92% water and is related to cucumbers and pumpkins.

name: cantaloupe
fun_fact: Cantaloupe is named after the Italian town of Cantalupo.

name: honeydew
fun_fact: Honeydew melons are in the same family as cucumbers and squash.

name: pineapple
fun_fact: A pineapple takes about two years to grow from planting to harvest.

name: mango
fun_fact: Mangoes are the most consumed fruit in the world.

name: papaya
fun_fact: Papaya contains an enzyme called papain that can tenderize meat.

name: kiwi
fun_fact: Kiwis have more vitamin C per ounce than oranges.

name: peach
fun_fact: Peaches and nectarines are genetically almost identical — just one gene controls the fuzz.

name: plum
fun_fact: Dried plums (prunes) were rebranded because the name 'prune' had an image problem.

name: cherry
fun_fact: It takes about 250 cherries to make a cherry pie.

name: apricot
fun_fact: Apricots were first cultivated in China over 4,000 years ago.

name: pear
fun_fact: Pears ripen from the inside out, which is why they often feel soft near the core first.

name: lemon
fun_fact: Lemons contain more sugar than strawberries.

name: lime
fun_fact: British sailors earned the nickname 'limeys' because they ate limes to prevent scurvy.

name: grapefruit
fun_fact: Grapefruit can interact with over 85 medications.

name: tangerine
fun_fact: Tangerines are named after Tangier, Morocco, where they were first shipped to Europe.

name: pomegranate
fun_fact: A single pomegranate can contain over 600 seeds.

name: coconut
fun_fact: Coconut water can be used as a substitute for blood plasma in emergencies.

name: avocado
fun_fact: Avocados are technically berries, and they don't ripen on the tree.

name: fig
fun_fact: Figs are technically inverted flowers, not fruits.

name: date
fun_fact: Date palms can produce fruit for over 100 years.

name: guava
fun_fact: Guava has four times the vitamin C of an orange.

name: passion fruit
fun_fact: Passion fruit is named after the Passion of Christ, not romantic passion.

name: lychee
fun_fact: Lychee has been cultivated in China for over 2,000 years.

name: dragon fruit
fun_fact: Dragon fruit comes from a cactus that only blooms at night.

name: starfruit
fun_fact: Starfruit is one of the few fruits that's star-shaped when sliced.

name: persimmon
fun_fact: Unripe persimmons contain so much tannin they can make your mouth feel numb.

name: kumquat
fun_fact: Kumquats are the only citrus fruit you eat whole — skin and all.

name: jackfruit
fun_fact: Jackfruit is the largest tree-borne fruit in the world, weighing up to 80 pounds.

name: durian
fun_fact: Durian is banned on public transport in several Asian countries due to its smell.

name: mangosteen
fun_fact: Mangosteen was once banned from import to the US because of fruit fly concerns.

name: rambutan
fun_fact: Rambutan means 'hairy' in Malay, referring to its spiky exterior.

name: cranberry
fun_fact: Cranberries bounce when they're ripe — farmers use this to test quality.

name: boysenberry
fun_fact: Boysenberries are a cross between raspberries, blackberries, and loganberries.

name: gooseberry
fun_fact: Gooseberries were once banned in the US because they spread a disease that killed pine trees.

name: elderberry
fun_fact: Raw elderberries are actually toxic — they must be cooked before eating.

name: mulberry
fun_fact: Silkworms eat only mulberry leaves.

name: currant
fun_fact: Blackcurrants were banned in the US for nearly 100 years to protect pine trees.

name: quince
fun_fact: Some historians believe the forbidden fruit in the Garden of Eden was a quince, not an apple.

name: tamarind
fun_fact: Tamarind is a key ingredient in Worcestershire sauce.

name: breadfruit
fun_fact: When cooked, breadfruit has a texture and taste similar to freshly baked bread.

name: soursop
fun_fact: Soursop can weigh up to 15 pounds and has a flavor like strawberry-pineapple.

name: loquat
fun_fact: Loquats are one of the few fruit trees that bloom in autumn and ripen in early spring.

name: plantain
fun_fact: Plantains must be cooked before eating — they're starchier and less sweet than bananas.

name: cacao
fun_fact: It takes about 400 cacao beans to make one pound of chocolate.

name: acai
fun_fact: Acai berries lose most of their antioxidant power within 24 hours of being picked.

name: goji berry
fun_fact: Goji berries have been used in traditional Chinese medicine for over 2,000 years.

name: yuzu
fun_fact: Yuzu is so prized in Japan that a single fruit can cost several dollars.

name: ugli fruit
fun_fact: Ugli fruit is a cross between a grapefruit, an orange, and a tangerine.

name: crabapple
fun_fact: All domestic apples are descended from wild crabapples.

name: damson
fun_fact: Damsons have been grown in Britain since Roman times.

name: feijoa
fun_fact: Feijoa petals are edible and taste like cotton candy.

name: miracle fruit
fun_fact: Miracle fruit makes sour foods taste sweet for up to an hour after eating it.

name: noni
fun_fact: Noni fruit smells so bad it's sometimes called 'vomit fruit.'

name: rhubarb
fun_fact: Rhubarb leaves are poisonous, but the stalks are perfectly safe to eat.

name: salak
fun_fact: Salak is called 'snake fruit' because its skin looks like snake scales.

name: sapodilla
fun_fact: Sapodilla tree sap was the original base for chewing gum.

name: ackee
fun_fact: Ackee is the national fruit of Jamaica but is toxic if eaten before it's fully ripe.

name: cherimoya
fun_fact: Mark Twain called cherimoya 'the most delicious fruit known to men.'

name: horned melon
fun_fact: Horned melon tastes like a combination of banana, cucumber, and lime.

name: jabuticaba
fun_fact: Jabuticaba fruits grow directly on the trunk of the tree, not on branches.

name: longan
fun_fact: Longan means 'dragon eye' in Chinese because the fruit resembles an eyeball when peeled.

name: physalis
fun_fact: Physalis fruits come wrapped in their own papery lantern-like husk.

name: carrot
fun_fact: Carrots were originally purple — orange carrots were bred in the Netherlands in the 17th century.

name: broccoli
fun_fact: Broccoli is a human-engineered plant bred from wild cabbage.

name: cauliflower
fun_fact: Cauliflower comes in purple, green, and orange varieties, not just white.

name: spinach
fun_fact: Spinach loses about 90% of its nutrients within 24 hours of being picked.

name: kale
fun_fact: Kale was one of the most common green vegetables in Europe until the Middle Ages.

name: lettuce
fun_fact: Lettuce is a member of the sunflower family.

name: tomato
fun_fact: Tomatoes were once considered poisonous in Europe and called 'poison apples.'

name: potato
fun_fact: The potato was the first vegetable to be grown in space.

name: sweet potato
fun_fact: Sweet potatoes are not related to regular potatoes — they're in the morning glory family.

name: onion
fun_fact: Onions make you cry because they release a sulfur-based gas when cut.

name: garlic
fun_fact: There's a garlic festival in Gilroy, California that attracts over 100,000 people annually.

name: bell pepper
fun_fact: Green, yellow, and red bell peppers are actually the same vegetable at different stages of ripeness.

name: cucumber
fun_fact: Cucumbers are 96% water, making them one of the most hydrating foods.

name: zucchini
fun_fact: The world's largest zucchini on record weighed over 65 pounds.

name: eggplant
fun_fact: Eggplant is technically a berry and is related to tomatoes and tobacco.

name: celery
fun_fact: Celery has negative calories — it takes more energy to digest than it contains.

name: asparagus
fun_fact: Asparagus can grow up to 10 inches in a single day.

name: corn
fun_fact: Each ear of corn has an even number of rows, typically 16.

name: pea
fun_fact: Gregor Mendel used pea plants to discover the laws of genetics.

name: green bean
fun_fact: Green beans are picked before their seeds fully develop — that's why they're tender.

name: brussels sprout
fun_fact: Brussels sprouts grow on a tall stalk, clustered like tiny cabbages.

name: cabbage
fun_fact: Ancient Romans believed eating cabbage before drinking would prevent drunkenness.

name: artichoke
fun_fact: Artichokes are actually flower buds — if left unharvested, they bloom into purple flowers.

name: beet
fun_fact: Beetroot juice was used as a natural dye for lips and cheeks in the Victorian era.

name: radish
fun_fact: Radishes were paid as 'wages' to Egyptian pyramid builders.

name: turnip
fun_fact: Before pumpkins, people in Ireland carved turnips for Halloween jack-o'-lanterns.

name: parsnip
fun_fact: Parsnips get sweeter after a frost because the cold converts their starch to sugar.

name: fennel
fun_fact: Marathon, the Greek city, was named after fennel — 'marathon' means 'place of fennel.'

name: leek
fun_fact: The leek is the national emblem of Wales.

name: scallion
fun_fact: Scallions, green onions, and spring onions are all essentially the same thing.

name: shallot
fun_fact: Shallots grow in clusters like garlic rather than as single bulbs like onions.

name: chili pepper
fun_fact: The heat of chili peppers comes from capsaicin, which birds can't taste at all.

name: okra
fun_fact: Okra pods can grow from flower to harvest-ready in just two days.

name: chard
fun_fact: Swiss chard has nothing to do with Switzerland — a Swiss botanist just named it.

name: collard greens
fun_fact: Collard greens have been cultivated for over 2,000 years.

name: bok choy
fun_fact: Bok choy has more calcium per ounce than milk.

name: watercress
fun_fact: Watercress was eaten by Roman soldiers to give them strength and vigor.

name: endive
fun_fact: Endive is grown in darkness to keep it pale and reduce bitterness.

name: kohlrabi
fun_fact: Kohlrabi means 'cabbage turnip' in German, though it tastes like neither.

name: rutabaga
fun_fact: Rutabaga is a cross between a cabbage and a turnip that occurred naturally.

name: jicama
fun_fact: Jicama roots are edible but the rest of the plant, including the seeds, is toxic.

name: taro
fun_fact: Taro is one of the oldest cultivated crops, grown for over 10,000 years.

name: cassava
fun_fact: Cassava is the third-largest source of carbohydrates in the tropics.

name: bamboo shoot
fun_fact: Bamboo is the fastest-growing plant on Earth, growing up to 35 inches per day.

name: water chestnut
fun_fact: Water chestnuts aren't nuts — they're aquatic vegetables that grow in marshes.

name: celeriac
fun_fact: Celeriac is the same species as celery but bred for its root instead of its stalks.

name: butternut squash
fun_fact: Butternut squash was developed in Massachusetts in the 1940s.

name: acorn squash
fun_fact: Acorn squash was a staple food for Native Americans long before European contact.

name: spaghetti squash
fun_fact: When cooked, spaghetti squash flesh separates into noodle-like strands naturally.

name: pumpkin
fun_fact: The heaviest pumpkin ever grown weighed over 2,700 pounds.

name: delicata squash
fun_fact: Delicata squash skin is edible, unlike most other winter squashes.

name: chayote
fun_fact: A chayote can sprout and grow a new plant while still sitting on your kitchen counter.

name: mushroom
fun_fact: Mushrooms are more closely related to humans than to plants.

name: yam
fun_fact: True yams can grow up to 5 feet long and weigh over 130 pounds.

name: horseradish
fun_fact: Horseradish releases its pungent oil only when the root cells are crushed or grated.

name: wasabi
fun_fact: Real wasabi is so hard to grow that most 'wasabi' served is actually dyed horseradish.

name: ginger
fun_fact: Ginger has been used medicinally for over 5,000 years.

name: turmeric
fun_fact: Turmeric has been used as a dye for Buddhist monks' robes for centuries.

name: lotus root
fun_fact: Lotus roots have a beautiful hole pattern that allows air to travel to submerged parts of the plant.

name: hearts of palm
fun_fact: Harvesting hearts of palm from a single-stemmed palm kills the entire tree.

name: romanesco
fun_fact: Romanesco grows in a perfect mathematical fractal pattern — each bud is a Fibonacci spiral.

name: broccoli rabe
fun_fact: Broccoli rabe is more closely related to turnips than to broccoli.

name: daikon
fun_fact: Daikon radishes can grow over 3 feet long and weigh up to 50 pounds.

name: edamame
fun_fact: Edamame are immature soybeans picked before they harden.

name: snap pea
fun_fact: Snap peas were created in the 1970s by crossing garden peas with snow peas.

name: samphire
fun_fact: Samphire grows wild on coastal rocks and naturally tastes salty.

name: fiddlehead
fun_fact: Fiddleheads are the curled fronds of young ferns, available for just a few weeks each spring.

name: nopales
fun_fact: Nopales are cactus paddles that have been a staple in Mexican cuisine for thousands of years.

name: sorrel
fun_fact: Sorrel's tangy lemony flavor comes from oxalic acid, the same compound found in rhubarb.

name: rice
fun_fact: Rice feeds more than half the world's population.

name: wheat
fun_fact: Wheat was one of the first crops domesticated by humans, around 10,000 years ago.

name: oat
fun_fact: Oats are the only cereal grain that naturally contain a significant amount of fat.

name: barley
fun_fact: Barley was the standard unit of measurement in ancient Mesopotamia.

name: corn
fun_fact: An ear of corn always has an even number of rows.

name: quinoa
fun_fact: Quinoa is not actually a grain — it's a seed related to spinach and beets.

name: millet
fun_fact: Millet was the first domesticated cereal grain, predating rice and wheat.

name: sorghum
fun_fact: Sorghum is the fifth most important cereal crop in the world.

name: buckwheat
fun_fact: Buckwheat isn't wheat at all — it's related to rhubarb.

name: rye
fun_fact: Rye can grow in poor soil and cold climates where other grains fail.

name: spelt
fun_fact: Spelt is an ancient grain that's been cultivated for over 7,000 years.

name: amaranth
fun_fact: Amaranth was a staple food of the Aztecs, who mixed it with blood for religious ceremonies.

name: teff
fun_fact: Teff grains are so tiny that one grain is only 1/150th the size of a wheat kernel.

name: farro
fun_fact: Farro fed the Roman legions as they conquered the ancient world.

name: freekeh
fun_fact: Freekeh is green wheat that's been roasted while still young, giving it a smoky flavor.

name: kamut
fun_fact: Kamut grains are two to three times the size of modern wheat.

name: triticale
fun_fact: Triticale is a human-made grain — a cross between wheat and rye created in the 1800s.

name: couscous
fun_fact: Couscous isn't a grain — it's tiny pasta made from semolina wheat.

name: bulgur
fun_fact: Bulgur is one of the fastest-cooking whole grains because it's already been parboiled.

name: semolina
fun_fact: Semolina is the coarse flour used to make pasta, couscous, and many desserts.

name: pasta
fun_fact: Traditional pasta is just durum wheat and water — humans have been eating it for over 2000 years.

name: cornmeal
fun_fact: Polenta was once considered peasant food in Italy but is now a gourmet staple.

name: einkorn
fun_fact: Einkorn is the oldest known variety of wheat, dating back 10,000 years.

name: tapioca
fun_fact: Tapioca comes from cassava root and is the basis for boba tea pearls.

name: wild rice
fun_fact: Wild rice isn't actually rice — it's the seed of an aquatic grass native to North America.

name: arborio rice
fun_fact: Arborio rice can absorb five times its weight in liquid, which is what makes risotto creamy.

name: jasmine rice
fun_fact: Jasmine rice gets its floral aroma from a compound also found in pandan leaves and popcorn.

name: basmati rice
fun_fact: Aged basmati rice is considered superior — some varieties are aged for up to two years.

name: flaxseed meal
fun_fact: Flaxseed meal was used by ancient Egyptians both as food and as a linen textile.

name: lentil
fun_fact: Lentils are one of the oldest cultivated foods, dating back over 9,000 years.

name: chickpea
fun_fact: Chickpeas are the most widely consumed legume in the world.

name: black bean
fun_fact: Black beans have as many antioxidants as grapes and cranberries.

name: kidney bean
fun_fact: Raw kidney beans contain a toxin that can cause severe nausea — always cook them first.

name: pinto bean
fun_fact: Pinto means 'painted' in Spanish, referring to the bean's speckled appearance.

name: navy bean
fun_fact: Navy beans got their name because the US Navy served them as a staple food in the 1800s.

name: lima bean
fun_fact: Lima beans are named after Lima, Peru, where they were first discovered by Europeans.

name: soybean
fun_fact: Soybeans are used to make everything from tofu to biodiesel fuel.

name: mung bean
fun_fact: Mung bean sprouts can grow 2-3 inches in just a few days.

name: adzuki bean
fun_fact: In Japan, adzuki beans are used to make sweet red bean paste for desserts.

name: fava bean
fun_fact: Pythagoras forbade his followers from eating fava beans for mysterious reasons.

name: green pea
fun_fact: The first peas were grown for their dried seeds, not eaten fresh like today.

name: split pea
fun_fact: Split peas are simply dried peas that have been peeled and split in half.

name: black-eyed pea
fun_fact: Eating black-eyed peas on New Year's Day is a tradition believed to bring good luck.

name: pigeon pea
fun_fact: Pigeon peas can fix nitrogen in the soil, making them great for sustainable farming.

name: cannellini bean
fun_fact: Cannellini beans are the most popular white bean in Italian cuisine.

name: cranberry bean
fun_fact: Cranberry beans lose their beautiful speckled pattern when cooked.

name: great northern bean
fun_fact: Great northern beans are medium-sized white beans popular in French cassoulet.

name: lupini bean
fun_fact: Lupini beans must be soaked for days to remove their natural bitter alkaloids.

name: peanut
fun_fact: Peanuts aren't nuts — they're legumes that grow underground.

name: mesquite
fun_fact: Mesquite pods were a primary food source for Native Americans in the Southwest.

name: carob
fun_fact: Carob seeds are so uniform in size they were used as the original carat weight for gemstones.

name: tamarind
fun_fact: Tamarind pod pulp is both sweet and sour and is used in cuisines across 5 continents.

name: alfalfa
fun_fact: Alfalfa roots can grow over 20 feet deep into the ground.

name: almond
fun_fact: Almonds are seeds, not true nuts — they're related to peaches and plums.

name: walnut
fun_fact: Walnut shells were used as explosives in World War II.

name: cashew
fun_fact: Cashews grow hanging from the bottom of a cashew apple fruit.

name: pistachio
fun_fact: Pistachios are sometimes called 'the smiling nut' in Iran and 'the happy nut' in China.

name: pecan
fun_fact: Pecans are the only major tree nut native to North America.

name: macadamia
fun_fact: Macadamia nuts have the hardest shell of any commercially sold nut.

name: hazelnut
fun_fact: About 70% of the world's hazelnuts come from Turkey.

name: brazil nut
fun_fact: Brazil nut trees can live for over 500 years and only grow in undisturbed rainforest.

name: chestnut
fun_fact: Chestnuts are the only nuts that contain vitamin C.

name: pine nut
fun_fact: It can take up to 25 years for a pine tree to start producing pine nut cones.

name: coconut
fun_fact: Coconuts are technically drupes, not nuts — and they can float across oceans to spread.

name: acorn
fun_fact: Acorns were a dietary staple for many Native American tribes for thousands of years.

name: kola nut
fun_fact: Kola nuts were the original source of caffeine in Coca-Cola.

name: tiger nut
fun_fact: Tiger nuts aren't nuts at all — they're small root vegetables (tubers).

name: candlenut
fun_fact: Candlenuts are so oily they were literally burned as candles in ancient Hawaii.

name: marcona almond
fun_fact: Marcona almonds are called the 'queen of almonds' and only grow in Spain.

name: mongongo nut
fun_fact: Mongongo nuts have been a staple food in southern Africa for over 7,000 years.

name: chia seed
fun_fact: Chia seeds can absorb up to 12 times their weight in water.

name: flaxseed
fun_fact: Flaxseed was cultivated in Babylon as early as 3000 BC.

name: hemp seed
fun_fact: Hemp seeds contain all 20 amino acids, including all 9 essential ones.

name: sunflower seed
fun_fact: A single sunflower head can contain up to 2,000 seeds.

name: pumpkin seed
fun_fact: Pumpkin seeds have been found in Mexican caves dating back over 7,000 years.

name: sesame seed
fun_fact: Sesame may be the oldest condiment known to man, dating back to 3000 BC.

name: poppy seed
fun_fact: Poppy seeds can cause a false positive on drug tests because they come from opium poppies.

name: fennel seed
fun_fact: Roman gladiators ate fennel seeds believing they gave them strength and courage.

name: cumin seed
fun_fact: Cumin is the second most popular spice in the world after black pepper.

name: coriander seed
fun_fact: Coriander seeds have been found in ancient Egyptian tombs dating back 3,000 years.

name: caraway seed
fun_fact: Caraway seeds are the key flavoring in rye bread.

name: mustard seed
fun_fact: It takes about 1,000 mustard seeds to make one tablespoon of prepared mustard.

name: nigella seed
fun_fact: Nigella seeds have been found in Tutankhamun's tomb and are called 'the seed of blessing.'

name: sacha inchi
fun_fact: Sacha inchi seeds contain more omega-3 than salmon.

name: watermelon seed
fun_fact: Roasted watermelon seeds are a popular snack in the Middle East and Asia.

name: lotus seed
fun_fact: Lotus seeds have been germinated after lying dormant for over 1,000 years.

name: basil seed
fun_fact: Basil seeds swell up into a gel-like coating when soaked, similar to chia seeds.

name: beef
fun_fact: Beef from grass-fed cattle has a different fatty acid profile than grain-fed.

name: pork
fun_fact: Pork is the most widely consumed meat in the world.

name: lamb
fun_fact: Lamb under one year old is called lamb; over one year is called mutton.

name: veal
fun_fact: Veal has been considered a delicacy since ancient Roman times.

name: venison
fun_fact: Venison comes from the Latin 'venari,' meaning 'to hunt.'

name: bison
fun_fact: Bison meat has less fat and cholesterol than chicken breast.

name: rabbit
fun_fact: Rabbit was the most commonly consumed meat in medieval Europe.

name: goat
fun_fact: Goat is the most widely consumed red meat globally.

name: elk
fun_fact: Elk antlers can grow up to an inch per day, making them one of the fastest-growing bones.

name: wild boar
fun_fact: Wild boar is the ancestor of all domestic pig breeds.

name: horse
fun_fact: Horse meat is a delicacy in many countries including France, Japan, and Kazakhstan.

name: kangaroo
fun_fact: Kangaroo meat is extremely lean, with less than 2% fat.

name: ostrich
fun_fact: Ostrich meat looks and tastes more like beef than poultry despite being a bird.

name: alligator
fun_fact: Alligator meat tastes like a mild cross between chicken and fish.

name: frog legs
fun_fact: France consumes an estimated 80 million frogs per year.

name: prosciutto
fun_fact: Authentic prosciutto di Parma takes at least 12 months to cure.

name: salami
fun_fact: Salami was invented as a way to preserve meat before refrigeration existed.

name: bresaola
fun_fact: Bresaola is air-dried beef that originated in the Lombardy region of Italy.

name: pancetta
fun_fact: Pancetta is Italian bacon that's cured but not smoked.

name: chorizo
fun_fact: Spanish and Mexican chorizo are completely different — Spanish is cured, Mexican is fresh.

name: corned beef
fun_fact: The 'corn' in corned beef refers to the large grains of salt used to cure it.

name: jerky
fun_fact: Jerky comes from the Quechua word 'ch'arki,' meaning dried meat.

name: pastrami
fun_fact: Pastrami was invented by Romanian Jews as a way to preserve goose meat.

name: sopressata
fun_fact: Sopressata is pressed flat during curing, which gives it its name and distinctive shape.

name: chicken
fun_fact: There are more chickens on Earth than any other bird — about 25 billion.

name: turkey
fun_fact: Benjamin Franklin wanted the turkey, not the bald eagle, as America's national bird.

name: duck
fun_fact: Ducks have waterproof feathers — even when they dive underwater, the downy layer stays dry.

name: goose
fun_fact: Geese mate for life and can live over 20 years.

name: quail
fun_fact: Quail eggs are considered a delicacy and have proportionally larger yolks than chicken eggs.

name: pheasant
fun_fact: Male pheasants are so colorful because they need to attract females who are plain brown.

name: guinea fowl
fun_fact: Guinea fowl are excellent at controlling tick populations.

name: cornish hen
fun_fact: Cornish hens aren't a separate breed — they're just young chickens harvested early.

name: squab
fun_fact: Squab (young pigeon) was a common luxury food in ancient Egypt and Rome.

name: partridge
fun_fact: The 'partridge in a pear tree' from the Christmas song is actually a red-legged partridge.

name: grouse
fun_fact: The opening of grouse hunting season on August 12 is called 'The Glorious Twelfth' in Britain.

name: emu
fun_fact: Emu meat is very dark red, lean, and tastes similar to beef.

name: dove
fun_fact: Doves have been eaten as a game bird for thousands of years across the Mediterranean.

name: capon
fun_fact: A capon is a castrated rooster, which makes the meat more tender and flavorful.

name: salmon
fun_fact: Salmon can jump up to 12 feet in the air to get past waterfalls.

name: tuna
fun_fact: A single bluefin tuna sold for $3.1 million at a Tokyo auction in 2019.

name: cod
fun_fact: Cod was so important to early American history that a wooden carving of one hangs in the Massachusetts State House.

name: tilapia
fun_fact: Tilapia is one of the oldest farmed fish — ancient Egyptians raised them over 4,000 years ago.

name: halibut
fun_fact: Halibut can weigh over 500 pounds and live for more than 50 years.

name: trout
fun_fact: Rainbow trout and steelhead are actually the same species — the difference is lifestyle.

name: bass
fun_fact: Chilean sea bass was originally called 'Patagonian toothfish' until a fish dealer rebranded it.

name: sardine
fun_fact: Sardines are named after the Italian island of Sardinia, where they were once abundant.

name: anchovy
fun_fact: Anchovies are the secret ingredient in Worcestershire sauce and Caesar dressing.

name: mackerel
fun_fact: Mackerel can swim at speeds of up to 33 miles per hour.

name: swordfish
fun_fact: A swordfish's bill can reach temperatures of up to 80°F warmer than surrounding water.

name: mahi mahi
fun_fact: Mahi mahi means 'strong strong' in Hawaiian.

name: snapper
fun_fact: Red snapper is so commonly mislabeled that studies found 73% of fish sold as snapper was something else.

name: grouper
fun_fact: Some grouper species can change sex from female to male as they age.

name: catfish
fun_fact: Catfish have over 100,000 taste buds — covering their entire body.

name: flounder
fun_fact: Flounder are born with eyes on both sides but one eye migrates as they grow.

name: sole
fun_fact: Dover sole was named after the English port of Dover where it was commonly landed.

name: haddock
fun_fact: Haddock has a distinctive dark blotch on each side called 'Saint Peter's thumbprint.'

name: pollock
fun_fact: Most imitation crab meat is actually made from pollock.

name: perch
fun_fact: Perch are one of the most widely distributed freshwater fish in North America.

name: pike
fun_fact: Northern pike can live over 25 years and have razor-sharp teeth.

name: monkfish
fun_fact: Monkfish is called 'poor man's lobster' because its tail meat has a similar texture.

name: barramundi
fun_fact: Barramundi can change sex — they start as males and become females later in life.

name: branzino
fun_fact: Branzino is one of the most popular fish in Mediterranean cuisine.

name: eel
fun_fact: No one has ever observed eels mating — their reproduction is one of nature's biggest mysteries.

name: herring
fun_fact: Herring communicate by releasing bubbles from their rear end — scientists call it 'fast repetitive tick' sounds.

name: carp
fun_fact: Koi fish are just selectively bred carp that can live over 200 years.

name: whitefish
fun_fact: Whitefish is one of the most popular smoked fish in Jewish delicatessen cuisine.

name: wahoo
fun_fact: Wahoo can swim at speeds up to 60 mph, making it one of the fastest fish in the ocean.

name: arctic char
fun_fact: Arctic char is the most northerly freshwater fish in the world.

name: bluefish
fun_fact: Bluefish are such aggressive predators they sometimes keep killing even after they're full.

name: pompano
fun_fact: Pompano is considered one of the finest eating fish in the Gulf of Mexico.

name: skate
fun_fact: Skate wings develop a better flavor a day or two after being caught.

name: turbot
fun_fact: Turbot was so prized by the Romans that they had special diamond-shaped platters made for it.

name: john dory
fun_fact: John Dory has a distinctive dark spot on each side, said to be Saint Peter's thumbprint.

name: lingcod
fun_fact: Lingcod sometimes have bright blue or green flesh, which turns white when cooked.

name: opah
fun_fact: Opah is the only known fully warm-blooded fish.

name: sturgeon
fun_fact: Sturgeons have been around for over 200 million years — they're older than dinosaurs.

name: cobia
fun_fact: Cobia have no swim bladder and must keep swimming to avoid sinking.

name: yellowtail
fun_fact: Yellowtail hamachi is the most popular sushi fish in Japan.

name: shrimp
fun_fact: A shrimp's heart is in its head.

name: crab
fun_fact: Crabs' teeth are in their stomachs.

name: lobster
fun_fact: Lobsters were once considered poverty food — prisoners and servants complained about eating them.

name: clam
fun_fact: The oldest known animal ever was a clam named Ming, which lived to be 507 years old.

name: mussel
fun_fact: Mussels attach to surfaces using incredibly strong threads called byssal threads.

name: oyster
fun_fact: A single oyster can filter up to 50 gallons of water per day.

name: scallop
fun_fact: Scallops have up to 200 tiny eyes that can detect movement and light.

name: squid
fun_fact: Squid have three hearts and blue blood.

name: octopus
fun_fact: Octopuses have three hearts, nine brains, and blue blood.

name: crawfish
fun_fact: Louisiana produces 90% of the crawfish consumed in the United States.

name: conch
fun_fact: Queen conch can live up to 30 years and grow shells up to 12 inches long.

name: abalone
fun_fact: Abalone shells are lined with nacre (mother of pearl), one of the strongest natural materials.

name: sea urchin
fun_fact: Sea urchin 'meat' (uni) is actually the animal's reproductive organs.

name: whelk
fun_fact: Whelks are predatory sea snails that drill holes through other shellfish to eat them.

name: periwinkle
fun_fact: Periwinkles are tiny sea snails commonly eaten as street food in Europe and Africa.

name: cuttlefish
fun_fact: Cuttlefish can change their skin color and texture in less than a second.

name: barnacle
fun_fact: Percebes (goose barnacles) are a delicacy in Spain that sell for over $100 per pound.

name: cockle
fun_fact: The phrase 'warming the cockles of your heart' refers to these heart-shaped shellfish.

name: razor clam
fun_fact: Razor clams can burrow into sand at a rate of about one centimeter per second.

name: langoustine
fun_fact: Langoustines are what most of Europe calls 'scampi.'

name: milk
fun_fact: Milk is the only food designed specifically to be food.

name: cheese
fun_fact: There are over 1,800 named varieties of cheese in the world.

name: cheddar
fun_fact: Cheddar cheese originated in the English village of Cheddar in Somerset.

name: mozzarella
fun_fact: Real mozzarella di bufala is made from water buffalo milk, not cow's milk.

name: parmesan
fun_fact: Authentic Parmigiano-Reggiano must be aged for at least 12 months.

name: brie
fun_fact: Brie was called the 'king of cheeses' at a cheese competition in 1815.

name: gouda
fun_fact: Gouda accounts for 50-60% of all cheese consumed in the world.

name: feta
fun_fact: Under EU law, only cheese made in Greece from sheep's and goat's milk can be called feta.

name: swiss cheese
fun_fact: The holes in Swiss cheese are caused by carbon dioxide released by bacteria during aging.

name: blue cheese
fun_fact: Blue cheese gets its distinctive veins from Penicillium mold — the same genus as the antibiotic.

name: cream cheese
fun_fact: Cream cheese was invented by accident by an American dairyman in 1872.

name: ricotta
fun_fact: Ricotta means 'recooked' — it's made from whey left over from other cheese production.

name: cottage cheese
fun_fact: Cottage cheese was likely the first cheese ever made in America.

name: goat cheese
fun_fact: Goat cheese is easier to digest than cow's milk cheese for many people.

name: mascarpone
fun_fact: Mascarpone is the key ingredient in tiramisu.

name: camembert
fun_fact: During World War I, camembert was issued to French soldiers as part of their rations.

name: halloumi
fun_fact: Halloumi has such a high melting point that you can grill or fry it like meat.

name: manchego
fun_fact: Authentic Manchego must be made from milk of Manchega sheep in La Mancha, Spain.

name: pecorino
fun_fact: Pecorino Romano was part of the diet of Roman legionnaires 2,000 years ago.

name: provolone
fun_fact: Provolone is hung from the ceiling to age, which is why it's often pear-shaped.

name: butter
fun_fact: It takes about 21 pounds of milk to make one pound of butter.

name: yogurt
fun_fact: Yogurt has been eaten for over 7,000 years.

name: cream
fun_fact: Clotted cream is made by slowly heating cream until it forms thick golden clots.

name: whey
fun_fact: Whey was once discarded as waste until bodybuilders popularized whey protein supplements.

name: paneer
fun_fact: Paneer doesn't melt because it's made by curdling milk with acid instead of rennet.

name: queso fresco
fun_fact: Queso fresco crumbles rather than melts, making it perfect as a topping.

name: havarti
fun_fact: Havarti was invented in the 1800s by Hanne Nielsen on her farm in Denmark.

name: muenster
fun_fact: The orange rind on Muenster cheese is colored with annatto, a natural plant dye.

name: limburger
fun_fact: Limburger is famous for its strong smell, which is caused by the same bacteria found on human skin.

name: asiago
fun_fact: Asiago has been made on the Asiago Plateau in Italy for over 1,000 years.

name: fontina
fun_fact: Fontina is one of Italy's great melting cheeses and is essential for fonduta.

name: chicken egg
fun_fact: A hen can lay about 300 eggs per year.

name: duck egg
fun_fact: Duck eggs have nearly twice the nutritional value of chicken eggs.

name: quail egg
fun_fact: Quail eggs are considered a remedy for allergies in several traditional medicine systems.

name: goose egg
fun_fact: A single goose egg is equivalent to about three chicken eggs.

name: ostrich egg
fun_fact: One ostrich egg equals about 24 chicken eggs and takes 2 hours to hard-boil.

name: turkey egg
fun_fact: Turkey eggs are edible and delicious but rarely sold because turkeys lay far fewer than chickens.

name: caviar
fun_fact: Beluga caviar from the Caspian Sea can cost over $10,000 per kilogram.

name: basil
fun_fact: In Italy, basil is a symbol of love — suitors traditionally give basil to their beloved.

name: cilantro
fun_fact: About 14% of people have a gene that makes cilantro taste like soap.

name: parsley
fun_fact: Ancient Greeks used parsley to crown victors of athletic competitions.

name: mint
fun_fact: Mint is so invasive that gardeners are advised to grow it in containers to prevent it from taking over.

name: dill
fun_fact: The word 'dill' comes from Old Norse 'dilla,' meaning 'to soothe.'

name: rosemary
fun_fact: Rosemary has been shown to improve memory — students in ancient Greece wore it during exams.

name: thyme
fun_fact: Ancient Egyptians used thyme for embalming their dead.

name: sage
fun_fact: The name 'sage' comes from the Latin 'salvare,' meaning 'to save' or 'to heal.'

name: oregano
fun_fact: Oregano only became popular in America after WWII soldiers brought a taste for it back from Italy.

name: chive
fun_fact: Chives are the only allium species found growing wild on three continents.

name: tarragon
fun_fact: Tarragon was used in medieval times as a cure for snake bites.

name: bay leaf
fun_fact: Ancient Greeks and Romans crowned their heroes with wreaths of bay laurel leaves.

name: lemongrass
fun_fact: Lemongrass contains citral, the same compound that gives lemons their scent.

name: marjoram
fun_fact: Ancient Greeks believed marjoram was created by Aphrodite as a symbol of happiness.

name: lavender
fun_fact: Lavender comes from the Latin 'lavare,' meaning 'to wash' — Romans added it to bath water.

name: chamomile
fun_fact: Chamomile tea is one of the most widely consumed herbal teas in the world.

name: lemon balm
fun_fact: Lemon balm has been cultivated for over 2,000 years to attract honeybees.

name: savory
fun_fact: Savory was used as a flavoring before pepper was widely available in Europe.

name: epazote
fun_fact: Epazote is added to beans in Mexican cooking because it's believed to reduce gas.

name: curry leaf
fun_fact: Curry leaves are not related to curry powder — they're from a completely different plant.

name: shiso
fun_fact: Shiso comes in green and purple varieties and is a staple garnish in Japanese cuisine.

name: culantro
fun_fact: Culantro looks nothing like cilantro but has 10 times stronger flavor.

name: woodruff
fun_fact: Woodruff is used to flavor May wine and German Waldmeister ice cream.

name: borage
fun_fact: Borage flowers taste like cucumber and are used to garnish cocktails.

name: chervil
fun_fact: Chervil is one of the four herbs in the classic French 'fines herbes' blend.

name: lovage
fun_fact: Lovage tastes like a strong cross between celery and parsley.

name: black pepper
fun_fact: In medieval Europe, black pepper was so valuable it was used as currency.

name: cinnamon
fun_fact: Most 'cinnamon' sold in stores is actually cassia, a related but cheaper spice.

name: turmeric
fun_fact: Turmeric's bright yellow color has been used as a fabric dye for centuries.

name: cumin
fun_fact: Cumin seeds have been found in ancient Syrian archaeological sites dating back 4,000 years.

name: paprika
fun_fact: Paprika is the national spice of Hungary and is central to dishes like goulash.

name: ginger
fun_fact: Ginger can help reduce nausea and has been used as a natural remedy for motion sickness.

name: nutmeg
fun_fact: In the 1600s, nutmeg was so valuable that control of nutmeg islands sparked wars.

name: clove
fun_fact: Cloves contain eugenol, a natural anesthetic — chewing one can numb a toothache.

name: cardamom
fun_fact: Cardamom is the third most expensive spice in the world, after saffron and vanilla.

name: saffron
fun_fact: Saffron is the world's most expensive spice — it takes 75,000 flowers to make one pound.

name: vanilla
fun_fact: Vanilla is the only edible fruit of the orchid family.

name: coriander
fun_fact: Coriander seeds and cilantro leaves come from the same plant but taste completely different.

name: chili powder
fun_fact: Chili powder is actually a blend of spices, not just ground chilies.

name: cayenne
fun_fact: Cayenne pepper can temporarily boost metabolism by up to 20%.

name: allspice
fun_fact: Allspice is a single spice that tastes like a combination of cinnamon, nutmeg, and cloves.

name: star anise
fun_fact: Star anise is the source of shikimic acid, a key ingredient in the flu medication Tamiflu.

name: fenugreek
fun_fact: Eating fenugreek can make your sweat and urine smell like maple syrup.

name: sumac
fun_fact: Sumac was used as a souring agent in the Middle East long before lemons arrived from Asia.

name: za'atar
fun_fact: Za'atar is a blend of herbs and spices that has been eaten in the Middle East since ancient times.

name: five spice
fun_fact: Chinese five spice is designed to balance all five flavors: sweet, sour, bitter, salty, and umami.

name: mace
fun_fact: Mace is the lacy red covering that surrounds the nutmeg seed — they're from the same fruit.

name: juniper berry
fun_fact: Juniper berries are the key flavoring ingredient in gin.

name: annatto
fun_fact: Annatto gives Cheddar cheese, Velveeta, and even some butters their orange-yellow color.

name: grains of paradise
fun_fact: Grains of paradise were once used to flavor beer in medieval Europe before hops took over.

name: asafoetida
fun_fact: Asafoetida smells terrible raw but becomes savory and onion-like when cooked.

name: szechuan pepper
fun_fact: Szechuan pepper creates a tingling, numbing sensation rather than heat.

name: white pepper
fun_fact: White pepper is just black pepper with the outer layer removed.

name: pink peppercorn
fun_fact: Pink peppercorns aren't actually pepper — they're berries from a South American tree.

name: anise
fun_fact: Anise is the flavor behind licorice, absinthe, and ouzo.

name: mustard powder
fun_fact: Mustard is one of the oldest known spices, with evidence of use dating back 5,000 years.

name: celery seed
fun_fact: Celery seed is a key ingredient in Old Bay seasoning.

name: olive oil
fun_fact: It takes about 1,500 olives to make one liter of olive oil.

name: coconut oil
fun_fact: Coconut oil is one of the few plant-based sources of saturated fat.

name: sesame oil
fun_fact: Sesame oil was used as a cooking oil in ancient Babylon over 4,000 years ago.

name: avocado oil
fun_fact: Avocado oil has the highest smoke point of any unrefined oil.

name: peanut oil
fun_fact: Peanut oil is popular for deep frying because it doesn't absorb flavors from food.

name: walnut oil
fun_fact: Walnut oil was used by Renaissance painters like Leonardo da Vinci to thin paint.

name: flaxseed oil
fun_fact: Flaxseed oil has the highest omega-3 content of any plant oil.

name: truffle oil
fun_fact: Most truffle oil contains no actual truffles — it's made with a synthetic chemical.

name: hemp oil
fun_fact: Hemp oil has the ideal 3:1 ratio of omega-6 to omega-3 fatty acids.

name: macadamia oil
fun_fact: Macadamia oil has the highest monounsaturated fat content of any oil.

name: honey
fun_fact: Honey never spoils — 3,000-year-old honey from Egyptian tombs was still edible.

name: maple syrup
fun_fact: It takes about 40 gallons of maple sap to make just one gallon of maple syrup.

name: agave
fun_fact: Agave is the same plant used to make tequila.

name: molasses
fun_fact: The Great Molasses Flood of 1919 killed 21 people when a tank burst in Boston.

name: coconut sugar
fun_fact: Coconut sugar comes from the sap of coconut flower buds, not the coconut itself.

name: date syrup
fun_fact: Date syrup has been used as a sweetener in the Middle East for over 5,000 years.

name: stevia
fun_fact: Stevia is up to 300 times sweeter than sugar but has zero calories.

name: monk fruit
fun_fact: Monk fruit has been used as a sweetener in China for hundreds of years.

name: brown rice syrup
fun_fact: Brown rice syrup is made by breaking down the starch in cooked rice with enzymes.

name: birch syrup
fun_fact: Birch syrup requires 100 gallons of sap to make one gallon — 2.5x more than maple.

name: muscovado sugar
fun_fact: Muscovado is the least refined form of cane sugar, retaining all its original molasses.

name: jaggery
fun_fact: Jaggery is unrefined cane sugar used across South Asia, Africa, and Latin America.

name: kimchi
fun_fact: There are over 200 varieties of kimchi in Korea.

name: sauerkraut
fun_fact: Sauerkraut was brought on long sea voyages to prevent scurvy — it's rich in vitamin C.

name: miso
fun_fact: Some miso pastes are aged for over three years to develop deep, complex flavors.

name: tempeh
fun_fact: Tempeh originated in Java, Indonesia, over 300 years ago.

name: kombucha
fun_fact: Kombucha is fermented using a SCOBY — a symbiotic culture of bacteria and yeast.

name: tofu
fun_fact: Tofu was invented in China over 2,000 years ago, possibly by accident.

name: soy sauce
fun_fact: Traditional soy sauce takes 6 months to 2 years to ferment.

name: fish sauce
fun_fact: Ancient Romans had their own version of fish sauce called 'garum.'

name: natto
fun_fact: Natto is so sticky that it forms long, stringy threads when pulled apart.

name: kefir
fun_fact: Kefir grains are not actually grains — they're living symbiotic cultures.

name: sourdough
fun_fact: Some sourdough starters have been kept alive and fed for over 100 years.

name: pickles
fun_fact: Cleopatra attributed her beauty to eating pickles.

name: vinegar
fun_fact: Balsamic vinegar from Modena can be aged for over 25 years.

name: yogurt
fun_fact: The word 'yogurt' comes from Turkish and means 'to thicken.'

name: preserved lemon
fun_fact: Preserved lemons are a staple in Moroccan cuisine, adding intense citrus flavor.

name: injera
fun_fact: Injera bread is naturally fermented for 2-3 days, giving it a slightly sour taste.

name: kvass
fun_fact: Kvass is a fermented bread drink that's been popular in Russia for over 1,000 years.

name: tepache
fun_fact: Tepache is a Mexican fermented drink made from pineapple rinds and spices.

name: button mushroom
fun_fact: Button mushrooms, cremini, and portobello are all the same species at different stages of growth.

name: portobello
fun_fact: Portobellos are just mature cremini mushrooms that have been allowed to grow larger.

name: shiitake
fun_fact: Shiitake mushrooms have been cultivated in Japan for over 1,000 years.

name: oyster mushroom
fun_fact: Oyster mushrooms are one of the few carnivorous mushrooms — they trap and digest tiny worms.

name: chanterelle
fun_fact: Chanterelles cannot be commercially cultivated — they must be wild foraged.

name: porcini
fun_fact: Porcini means 'little pigs' in Italian.

name: morel
fun_fact: Morels appear only in spring and can sell for over $30 per pound.

name: truffle
fun_fact: White truffles from Alba, Italy, have sold for over $300,000 at auction.

name: enoki
fun_fact: Wild enoki mushrooms look completely different from the cultivated ones sold in stores.

name: maitake
fun_fact: Maitake means 'dancing mushroom' — foragers supposedly danced with joy upon finding them.

name: king trumpet
fun_fact: King trumpet mushrooms are the largest species in the oyster mushroom family.

name: lions mane
fun_fact: Lion's mane mushroom may stimulate nerve growth factor production in the brain.

name: wood ear
fun_fact: Wood ear mushrooms are used in traditional Chinese medicine to improve blood circulation.

name: matsutake
fun_fact: Matsutake mushrooms are so prized in Japan they're given as luxury gifts.

name: reishi
fun_fact: Reishi is called the 'mushroom of immortality' in traditional Chinese medicine.

name: chaga
fun_fact: Chaga looks like a chunk of burnt charcoal growing on birch trees.

name: hedgehog mushroom
fun_fact: Hedgehog mushrooms have tiny spines instead of gills underneath their caps.

name: black trumpet
fun_fact: Black trumpet mushrooms are also called 'trompette de la mort' (trumpet of death) despite being delicious.

name: nori
fun_fact: Nori was so valuable in ancient Japan that it was accepted as tax payment.

name: kelp
fun_fact: Giant kelp can grow up to 2 feet per day, making it one of the fastest-growing organisms.

name: wakame
fun_fact: Wakame is considered an invasive species in many countries outside Asia.

name: dulse
fun_fact: When fried, dulse tastes remarkably similar to bacon.

name: spirulina
fun_fact: Spirulina was a dietary staple of the Aztecs and is now studied as food for astronauts.

name: chlorella
fun_fact: Chlorella reproduces so quickly it can quadruple its cell count in less than a day.

name: kombu
fun_fact: Kombu is naturally rich in glutamate, which is why it's used to make dashi broth so savory.

name: hijiki
fun_fact: Hijiki has been a part of the Japanese diet for centuries and is traditionally served on holidays.

name: irish moss
fun_fact: Irish moss produces carrageenan, a thickener found in everything from ice cream to toothpaste.

name: agar
fun_fact: Agar is used as a vegetarian substitute for gelatin and was discovered by accident in Japan in the 1650s.

name: arame
fun_fact: Arame has a mild, semi-sweet flavor that makes it one of the most approachable seaweeds.

name: sea lettuce
fun_fact: Sea lettuce is one of the most widely distributed seaweeds, found on every ocean coast.

name: tea
fun_fact: All true tea comes from the same plant — Camellia sinensis.

name: coffee
fun_fact: Coffee was discovered by an Ethiopian goat herder who noticed his goats dancing after eating coffee berries.

name: cocoa
fun_fact: The Aztecs drank chocolate as a bitter, spicy beverage — sugar was added later by Europeans.

name: orange juice
fun_fact: Florida produces about 70% of the United States' total orange juice supply.

name: apple juice
fun_fact: Unpasteurized apple cider was one of the most popular beverages in colonial America.

name: lemonade
fun_fact: The first recorded lemonade was sold in Paris in 1630 as a mix of sparkling water, lemon juice, and honey.

name: coconut water
fun_fact: Coconut water is sterile inside the coconut and was used as IV fluid in emergencies.

name: pomegranate juice
fun_fact: Pomegranate juice has more antioxidants than red wine or green tea.

name: cranberry juice
fun_fact: Native Americans used cranberries to dye fabric and as a poultice for wounds.

name: ginger beer
fun_fact: Original ginger beer was actually alcoholic — the modern soft drink version came later.

name: horchata
fun_fact: Horchata varies by country — in Mexico it's made from rice, in Spain from tiger nuts.

name: yerba mate
fun_fact: Yerba mate contains caffeine and is traditionally shared from a single gourd with a metal straw.

name: rooibos
fun_fact: Rooibos only grows in a small region of South Africa and nowhere else on Earth.

name: hibiscus tea
fun_fact: Hibiscus tea is bright red, naturally tart, and drunk across dozens of cultures worldwide.

name: beet juice
fun_fact: Beet juice can temporarily improve athletic performance by up to 3%.

name: wheatgrass juice
fun_fact: One ounce of wheatgrass juice is nutritionally equivalent to about 2.5 pounds of vegetables.

name: bone broth
fun_fact: Bone broth has been a staple of traditional diets for thousands of years across virtually every culture.

name: tallow
fun_fact: Tallow was the primary cooking fat for thousands of years before seed oils were invented in the 1900s.

name: lard
fun_fact: Lard has more monounsaturated fat than butter and was the most popular cooking fat in America until Crisco appeared.

name: ghee
fun_fact: Ghee has been used in Indian cooking and Ayurvedic medicine for over 5,000 years.

name: duck fat
fun_fact: French fries were traditionally cooked in duck fat in Belgium, which is where they actually originate.

name: schmaltz
fun_fact: Schmaltz was the primary cooking fat in Eastern European Jewish cuisine for centuries.

name: goose fat
fun_fact: Goose fat has been prized in French cooking for centuries, especially for confit and roast potatoes.
